title: Why do voices crack when singing? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are several factors that can contribute to cracking or breaking. Here are the most common reasons. Incorrect resonance placement - resonance not in its proper area of the mouth to make the note “resonate” or ring properly.Not enough breath compression (support) to create a strong note. This results in the voice losing its “hold” on the note and the vocal cords either break apart or “crack” (partially breaking)Too much muscle tension in the neck resulting in a “strangled” or choked sound.Attempting to sing a note your voice is not trained to sing (outside your current vocal range). Extending vocal range is a slow, step-by-step process because the voice needs to learn flexibility and “release” of tension.Too much vocal cord compression and not enough diaphragmatic compression (“grip”) from the body. This creates a choked sound and the note simply can’t be created.THE MOST COMMON CAUSE is the switch from the posterior muscles of the voice to the anterior muscles hasn’t been trained properly so there is a gradual change of these muscles groups from lower resonance to upper resonance. I know this sounds complicated, but its not in practice. This is often referred to as “switching registers” (which is really bad terminology because there are no such things as vocal registers)

Oh that crack! That nasty crack…or is it? Well, there is a good reason for that crack. There are a number of factors, but the biggest being a lack or coordination between the muscles that control the lower part of your voice (TA muscles) and those that control the higher part of your voice (CT muscles). A good vocal coach can give you exercises that can strengthen both muscles separately and their coordinated hand off. Many singers have a default to one or the other and often times need to work on strengthening the weaker muscle before working on coordinating the hand off. But then there’s the other side of that coin…the break that’s actually wanted. Yep, there are many styles of music that actually incorporate that break. Yodeling anyone? Yes, the yodel is utilizing that break to it’s fullest. You’re most likely familiar with the music of the alps, but you can hear this yodel in today’s pop music. In fact, I made video on how to actually achieve what I’ve dubbed the Pop Yodel with one of my students.
